Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions US-BIOTA-Sao Paulo: A multidisciplinary framework for biodiversity prediction in the Brazilian Atlantic forest hotspot.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will explain and predict of the distribution of animal and plant species in the endangered yet megadiverse Brazilian Atlantic forest. The investigators will correlate biogeographic and environmental patterns across major clades in order to understand patterns in this biodiversity hotspot. The project will entail study of both climate and landscape, and their changes over the last 120,000 years. This information will enable understanding of how species have responded to repeated environmental shifts of the past. Data from Earth-orbiting satellites will be combined with meteorological data and paleoenvironmental information from the fossil pollen record and ancient precipitation data derived from the geochemistry of deposits found in caves. These data, combined with information on modern species ranges, genetic diversity, physiological tolerances, host-pathogen dynamics, and regional shifts in the composition of the biota will demonstrate how the biodiversity of the Atlantic forest evolved over time.

This study will enable the reconstruction of historical factors influencing current biodiversity and, given a range of climate change scenarios, permit the prediction of the future composition of biodiversity in the Atlantic forest or elsewhere. Forest areas of geological stability, physical connectivity, and higher genetic diversity will be identified so that forests or species under extinction threat can be conserved. In response to current concern about the value of ecosystem services and climate change, this study provides a model of how to predict biodiversity change. The project also strengthens a minority-serving campus, ensuring that North-American students underrepresented in science are exposed to trans-disciplinary, international work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This aim of this project was to explain and predict the distribution of animal and plant species in the endangered yet megadiverse Brazilian Atlantic forest. While less than 10% of the original habitat in the Atlantic Forest remains, the biome is one of the richest on earth with over 15,000 plant species (half of them endemic). The project involved a multidisciplinary team working in five different countries studying species distribution, evolutionary and genetic patterns in selected groups of plants, birds, butterflies, harvestmen, lizards and amphibians.  These biodiversity data were integrated with current and past climate and geological data to recover recurring patterns of distribution in the Atlantic Forest. Past climate data were derived from analyses of speleothems and palynological lake cores. Present climate data were derived from both widely available models and remote sensing. This portion of this report deals mostly with the work of the botanical team or the interaction between the botanical work and the rest of the project members.

Through this project we have shown that many different type of organisms have similar distribution and endemicity patterns that are correlated with present and Holocene climatic patterns. While for some organisms these correlations may actually explain how these patterns arose, in other cases the ages of the clades or species groups far predate current climatic conditions and these similar patterns must be due to other causes. We also showed that while isolation by distance may be an important factor in shaping genetic patterns, especially in the lowland areas in northern Atlantic Forest, habitat suitability and/or geology may be a more important factor in southern Atlantic Forest. Regardless of the causes of origin and maintenance of this biodiversity, macroecological patterns of species richness and endemism are highly correlated with current climatic variables that can be measured or inferred through remote sensing technology.  While remote sensing technology is a great tool to discern broad patters, this can?t substitute the active presence of biologist in the ground as many new species and occurrence records have been described as result of this research

This project also had an important role in fostering the interactions of scientist from different institutions, strengthening academic collaborations between the US and Brazil and across US-based labs, as shown of continuing work product of these collaborations.  Broader impacts include a significant effort in training the next generation of biodirversity scientist thought training of four postdocs, and twelve graduate students and undergraduate students. Additionally, during the summer of 2019 the New York Botanical Garden had a garden-wide exhibit on the work of renown Brazilian landscape architect, naturalist, plant collector and horticulturalist Roberto Burle Marx.  As part of this exhibit the garden highlighted three of the main biomes of Brazil (Amazonia, Cerrado and Atlantic Forests) in a general public display, including digital media and objects that highlighted the plants, biomes of Brazil, as well as the gardens over 120 year history in the region and this project in particular.  The Burle Marx exhibit had a visitation of over 200,000 people.
